answers.answer: Todd,the fact that your not losing weight is a good sign. Black, maroon stools should be investigated. If you had a barium enema and it came out negative then this is good as it is a good procedure to detect colon cancer. Black, tarry stools could be attributed to ulcers or other upper GI bleeding. The endoscope will be a good idea to explore your upper GI to see if there is anything going on.

question: Ok..Here goes.I am a healthy (prior to this) 29 y/o male smoker, non drinker.About 5 months ago, started having terrible pains in my right eye on occasion.  These still occur once or twice per week and last for a few hours.  At about the same time, had a few episodes of dark red (maroon even) blood mixed in stool.  This also is continuing.  Also have had chronic diarrhea and fluffy loose stool (every day), sometimes with mucous as well.  Occasionally, have had episodes of darker (not quite black) tarry stool.  Have more recently begun to have upper left quadrant pains (aches) on a regular basis.  I have also recently (6 months) had an unexplained weight gain (approx. 25-30 lbs).  No change to diet, and I have actually increased my exercise during the last year.  Family hx has cancer all over the place, but non colonic, as well as diabetes (both sides) and M.S.Had barium enema (neg.) and waiting to hear back from stool samples for occult and parasite.  Also have appt. for an upper G.I. scope.Any thoughts would be appreciated... the digital exams are starting to get really old. :-)
